title: Academic Integrity Policy
content:
The University is committed to maintaining the highest standards of academic integrity. All students are expected to complete their own work and properly attribute the work of others. Academic integrity is fundamental to the pursuit of knowledge and the credibility of academic credentials.

Academic integrity violations include, but are not limited to: cheating on examinations, unauthorized collaboration on assignments, fabrication or falsification of data, plagiarism, and facilitating academic dishonesty by others. Students are responsible for understanding what constitutes a violation in each course, as expectations may vary by discipline and assignment type.

Faculty members are required to report all suspected violations to the Office of Academic Integrity. Upon receiving a report, the office will conduct a preliminary review to determine if a formal investigation is warranted. Students will be notified in writing of any allegations and given an opportunity to respond.

The University uses educational software tools to detect potential violations, including plagiarism detection services and proctoring software for online examinations. Students consent to the use of these tools by enrolling in courses.

All members of the academic community share responsibility for upholding these standards. Students who witness violations are encouraged to report them through the confidential reporting system. The University prohibits retaliation against anyone who reports a concern in good faith.
snippet: The University's academic integrity policy outlines standards for honest academic work and procedures for addressing violations.

title: Plagiarism Consequences and Sanctions
content:
Plagiarism is the presentation of another person's words, ideas, data, or creative work as one's own without proper attribution. This includes copying text without quotation marks, paraphrasing without citation, submitting work completed by others, and self-plagiarism (reusing one's own prior work without disclosure).

Sanctions for plagiarism are determined based on the severity of the violation, the student's academic history, and whether the violation was intentional. First-time minor violations may result in educational interventions, such as completing an academic integrity module, along with a reduced grade on the assignment.

More serious violations may result in failure of the assignment, failure of the course, suspension from the University, or permanent expulsion. A notation may be placed on the student's transcript indicating an academic integrity violation.

Students have the right to appeal sanctions through the Academic Appeals Committee. Appeals must be filed within 10 business days of receiving the sanction decision. The appeals process considers whether proper procedures were followed and whether the sanction is proportionate to the violation.

To avoid unintentional plagiarism, students should: take careful notes distinguishing their ideas from sources, use citation management software, allow time for revision, and consult with instructors or the Writing Center when uncertain. The library offers workshops on proper citation practices.
snippet: Learn about plagiarism types, sanctions ranging from grade penalties to expulsion, and the appeals process for academic integrity violations.

title: Student Code of Conduct
content:
The Student Code of Conduct establishes behavioral expectations for all enrolled students, both on and off campus when their actions affect the University community. Students are expected to conduct themselves with integrity, respect for others, and responsibility for their actions.

Prohibited conduct includes: physical violence or threats, harassment or intimidation, discrimination, theft or property damage, unauthorized entry, possession of weapons on campus, possession or distribution of illegal substances, disruptive behavior in academic settings, misuse of University resources, and violations of local, state, or federal law.

The conduct process begins when a report is filed with the Office of Student Conduct. Reports may be submitted by any member of the University community or external parties. The office will review the report and determine whether to proceed with an investigation.

Students accused of conduct violations will receive written notice of the charges and have the opportunity to meet with a conduct officer. Students may bring an advisor to all meetings. Cases may be resolved through administrative resolution or referred to a conduct board hearing.

Sanctions may include: warning, probation, educational requirements, restitution, loss of privileges, residence hall removal, suspension, or expulsion. Sanctions are designed to be educational and proportionate to the violation. Students may appeal decisions through the established appeals process within 5 business days.
snippet: The Student Code of Conduct outlines behavioral expectations and the conduct process for addressing violations on and off campus.

title: FERPA Rights for Students
content:
The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) is a federal law that protects the privacy of student education records. At the University, FERPA rights transfer to students when they enroll, regardless of age. Parents no longer have automatic access to records once a student is enrolled in postsecondary education.

Under FERPA, students have the right to: inspect and review their education records within 45 days of making a request, request amendments to records they believe are inaccurate or misleading, consent to disclosures of personally identifiable information (with certain exceptions), and file complaints with the U.S. Department of Education.

Education records include any records directly related to a student that are maintained by the University. This includes grades, transcripts, class schedules, financial aid information, and disciplinary records. FERPA does not cover records kept in the sole possession of the maker, law enforcement records, employment records, or medical records.

The University may disclose records without consent to: school officials with legitimate educational interest, other schools where the student seeks enrollment, specified officials for audit or evaluation purposes, appropriate parties in connection with financial aid, and in response to court orders or subpoenas.

Students may authorize release of their records to third parties, including parents, by completing the FERPA Release Form available through the Registrar's Office. This authorization can be limited to specific record types or time periods.
snippet: FERPA grants students rights to access, amend, and control disclosure of their education records. Learn about your privacy protections.

title: FERPA Directory Information Opt-Out
content:
Directory information is data that the University may disclose without student consent under FERPA. At this University, directory information includes: student name, University email address, major field of study, enrollment status (full-time/part-time), class level, dates of attendance, degrees and awards received, participation in officially recognized activities and sports, and photographs.

The University may release directory information to external parties, including employers, media outlets, and commercial entities. This information may appear in commencement programs, honor roll publications, athletic rosters, and the online student directory.

Students who do not wish to have their directory information disclosed may submit an opt-out request. To opt out, complete the Directory Information Restriction Form through your student portal or submit a written request to the Registrar's Office. Requests must be submitted by the end of the second week of each semester to be effective for that term.

Opting out means your name will not appear in the commencement program, you will not be included in the online directory, and the University will not verify your enrollment to third parties. This may affect your ability to receive certain services or recognitions.

Students should carefully consider the implications before opting out. The restriction remains in effect until you submit a written request to remove it. You may modify your directory information restrictions at any time by contacting the Registrar's Office.
snippet: Students may opt out of directory information disclosure under FERPA. Learn what information is included and how to restrict its release.

title: ADA Accommodations Process
content:
The University is committed to providing equal access to educational programs and activities for students with disabilities in compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. The Office of Disability Services (ODS) coordinates accommodations for eligible students.

To receive accommodations, students must register with ODS and provide documentation of their disability. Acceptable documentation varies by disability type but generally includes an evaluation from a qualified professional that describes the functional limitations and recommends specific accommodations. ODS will review documentation and meet with students to discuss accommodation needs.

Common academic accommodations include: extended time on exams, reduced-distraction testing environment, note-taking assistance, accessible formats for course materials, sign language interpreters, and flexible attendance policies for disability-related absences. Housing and dining accommodations are coordinated through separate processes.

Once approved, students receive an accommodation letter each semester to share with instructors. It is the student's responsibility to deliver accommodation letters and discuss implementation with each instructor at the beginning of the semester. Accommodations are not retroactive.

Students who believe they have been denied appropriate accommodations may file a grievance with the ADA/504 Coordinator. The University prohibits retaliation against students who request accommodations or file complaints. Faculty and staff questions about implementing accommodations should be directed to ODS.
snippet: Learn how to register for disability accommodations, what documentation is required, and how to work with faculty to implement approved accommodations.

title: Title IX Reporting and Resources
content:
Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 prohibits sex-based discrimination in educational programs and activities. This includes sexual harassment, sexual assault, dating violence, domestic violence, and stalking. The University is committed to maintaining an environment free from sex-based discrimination and providing support to affected individuals.

The University encourages anyone who experiences or witnesses potential Title IX violations to report them. Reports can be made to the Title IX Coordinator, any Responsible Employee (most faculty and staff), the campus police, or through the anonymous reporting hotline. The University will respond promptly and equitably to all reports.

Upon receiving a report, the Title IX Office will contact the complainant to discuss supportive measures and reporting options. Supportive measures may include: no-contact orders, academic accommodations, housing changes, counseling referrals, and safety planning. These measures are available regardless of whether a formal complaint is filed.

If a formal complaint is filed, the University will conduct an investigation following procedures outlined in the Title IX Grievance Policy. Both parties have equal rights throughout the process, including the right to an advisor, access to evidence, and the opportunity to appeal.

Confidential resources are available for those who wish to discuss their options without triggering a University response. Confidential resources include the Counseling Center, Student Health Services, and the Campus Advocacy Center. These offices will not share information without consent except in cases of imminent danger.
snippet: Title IX prohibits sex-based discrimination. Learn how to report incidents, access supportive measures, and find confidential resources.

title: Grade Appeal Process
content:
Students who believe a final course grade was assigned in error or through unfair processes may appeal through the Grade Appeal Process. Appeals must be based on one or more of the following grounds: computational or clerical error, grade based on factors other than academic performance, inconsistent application of grading standards, or deviation from the syllabus without notice.

Appeals must be initiated within 30 calendar days of the grade posting. The process begins with an informal resolution attempt. Students should first contact the instructor directly to discuss the grade concern. Many issues can be resolved through this conversation.

If informal resolution is unsuccessful, students may submit a formal written appeal to the department chair. The appeal must include: the course information, the grade received, specific grounds for appeal, supporting evidence, and the desired outcome. The department chair will review the appeal and may meet with both the student and instructor.

If the department chair's decision is unsatisfactory, students may escalate the appeal to the college dean's office. The dean or designee will conduct a final review and issue a binding decision. The entire appeal process typically takes 4-6 weeks.

Grade appeals do not extend the deadline for academic actions such as graduation applications or financial aid appeals. Students should consult with their academic advisor about potential impacts while an appeal is pending. The burden of proof rests with the student to demonstrate that the grade was improperly assigned.
snippet: Learn the process for appealing a final grade, including grounds for appeal, deadlines, and steps from informal resolution to formal review.

title: Academic Probation Policy
content:
Academic probation is a warning status indicating that a student's academic performance has fallen below the minimum standards required for continued enrollment. Students are placed on academic probation when their cumulative GPA falls below 2.0 or when they fail to meet specific program requirements.

Students on academic probation must meet with an academic advisor within the first two weeks of the following semester to develop an Academic Success Plan. This plan may include: reduced course load, mandatory tutoring, study skills workshops, and regular check-ins with the advisor. Students on probation may have limitations on extracurricular activities and leadership positions.

To be removed from probation, students must raise their cumulative GPA to 2.0 or above. Students who fail to meet this standard after one semester on probation will be placed on academic suspension. First suspension is typically for one semester, with longer suspension periods for subsequent occurrences.

Students may appeal their probation or suspension status if extenuating circumstances affected their academic performance. Appeals must be submitted in writing to the Academic Standards Committee and should include documentation of the circumstances and a plan for future success.

The University offers resources to help students succeed, including the Academic Success Center, peer tutoring, counseling services, and academic coaching. Students are encouraged to seek help early rather than waiting until they are struggling significantly.
snippet: Academic probation occurs when cumulative GPA falls below 2.0. Learn about requirements, success plans, and how to return to good standing.

title: Leave of Absence Policy
content:
A leave of absence (LOA) is a temporary interruption in a student's enrollment for personal, medical, family, military, or other reasons. Students in good academic standing may request a leave of absence for up to two consecutive semesters. Extensions may be granted in exceptional circumstances.

To request a leave of absence, students must complete the Leave of Absence Request Form through the Dean of Students Office. Requests should be submitted at least two weeks before the start of the semester when possible. Students must meet with their academic advisor to discuss the impact on their degree progress and financial aid.

During an approved leave, students retain their admitted status and are not required to reapply for admission. However, students returning from leave are subject to the catalog requirements in effect at the time of their return or may petition to continue under their original catalog.

Financial aid recipients should consult with the Financial Aid Office before taking a leave. Federal loans may enter repayment status during the leave period. Tuition and fee refunds are based on the withdrawal date and the University's refund schedule.

Students on leave may not use University facilities, attend classes, or participate in campus activities without prior approval. Health insurance coverage may continue through COBRA or similar arrangements. International students must consult with International Student Services regarding visa implications.

To return from leave, students must submit a Return from Leave Form at least 30 days before the intended return date. Medical leaves require clearance from the appropriate health provider.
snippet: A leave of absence allows temporary enrollment interruption while retaining admitted status. Learn about eligibility, procedures, and return requirements.
